case_name: National Cement Mines Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 84 of 1958 filed by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated December 22/23, 1955 in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 84 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22/23, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1953.

facts.text: Messrs. National Cement Mines Industries Ltd. are a public limited company incorporated to carry on business of cement and lime manufacture and limestone supply.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. National Cement Mines Industries Ltd.- hereinafter referred to as the appellants-are a public limited companypany incorporated to carry on the business of cement and lime manufacture and also of limestone supply and for the purposes of such businesses to acquire rights and companycessions pertaining to limestone, companyl and surface lands from the Dewar khand Karanpura Mines and Industries Ltd.

facts.text: Dewarkhand Karanpura Mines and Industries Ltd. obtained three leases on November 29, 1930: first for mining limestone, second and third for surface rights.

anchor.surface_text: Dewarkhand Karanpura Mines and Industries Ltd. hereinafter called the Karanpura Company -had obtained three leases on November 29, 1930, first for mining limestone from Maharaja Pratap Narain Udai Nath Shah Deo from limestone beds in certain villages in Dewarkhand, second from Maharaj Kumar Nand Kishore Nath Shah Deo of the surface rights neces. sary to exercise the powers and privileges in respect of the first lease and the third from Maharaj Kumar Raj Kishore Nath Shah Deo of surface rights in respect of Hoyer village.

facts.text: Each of the three leases had a period of thirty years.

anchor.surface_text: The period in each of the three leases was thirty years.

facts.text: On March 17, 1932, Karanpura Company conveyed the rights and options under the three leases to the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1932, the Karanpura Company companyveyed the rights and options under the three leases to the appellants.

facts.text: On September 30, 1934, appellants acquired limestone and surface rights in village Umedanda for 95 years from Maharaja Pratap Narain Uday Nath Shah Deo and Maharaj Kumar Raj Kishore Nath Shah Deo.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1934, the appellants acquired the limestone and surface rights in respect of limestone beds in village Umedanda for 95 years from Maharaja Pratap Narain Uday Nath Shah Deo and Maharaj Kumar Raj Kishore Nath Shah Deo.

facts.text: On September 30, 1934, appellants entered into bauxite option agreement with Maharaja Pratap Narain Uday Nath Shah Deo.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the appellants entered into two agreements, one with Maharaja Pratap Narain Uday Nath Shah Deo which is called the ,bauxite option agreement thereby acquiring the first option to take a lease or leases of any area or areas of bauxite deposits in certain villages,

facts.text: On September 30, 1934, fourth agreement reduced royalties under original deeds dated November 29, 1930, and extended lease periods to 99 years.

anchor.surface_text: By a fourth agreement also dated September 30,1934, between the Karanpura Company, Maharaja Pratap Narain Udai Nath Shah Deo acting with the companysent of Maharaj Kumars Raj Kishore Nath Shah Deo and Nand Kishore Nath Shah Deo, the royalties reserved under the original deeds dated November 29, 1930, were reduced and the periods of the leases were extended to 99 years from the date of the original leases,

facts.text: By deed dated May 7, 1935, appellants conveyed benefits of four leases and two agreements to Dewarkhand Cement Company Ltd. (later Associated Cement Ltd.) for Rs. 25,000 and further payments under covenants.

anchor.surface_text: By deed dated May 7,1935, the appellants companyveyed to Dewarkhand Cement Company Ltd.  which later came to be known as Associated Cement Ltd. and will be referred to hereinafter by that name  the benefits of the four leases and the two agreements for the unexpired periods. By this deed, for a present companysideration of Rs. 25,000 for trouble and expenses in obtaining the leases and agreements

facts.text: In the year of account June 1, 1944 to May 31, 1945, appellants received Rs. 77,820 from Associated Cement Ltd. under first covenant at rate of 0-13 As. per ton of cement manufactured from limestone won from the lands and sold.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account June 1, 1944, to May 31, 1945, the appellants received from the Associated Cement Ltd. under the first companyenant of the deed, Rs. 77,820 being the amount companyputed at the rate of 0-13 As. per ton of cement manufactured from limestone won from the lands and sold by the companypany.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Companies District 1, Calcutta, included Rs. 77,820 in appellants' total assessable income for assessment year 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Companies District 1, Calcutta, included this amount in the total assessable income of the appellants in the assessment year 1946-47.

facts.text: ITO's order confirmed in appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This order was companyfirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Calcutta High Court at instance of appellants.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellants, the Tribunal referred the following question with another number material for this appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta

facts.text: Tribunal held proved that principal objects of appellants included manufacturing cement and lime, sale of limestone, acquiring rights from Karanpura Company.

anchor.surface_text: The following facts were held proved by the Tribunal. The principal objects of incorporation of the appellants were to carry on the business of manufacturing cement and lime and sale of limestone and the appellants were formed with the object of acquiring the rights and companycessions of the Karanpura Company.

facts.text: Appellants were carrying on business in year of account 1944-45 for which incorporated.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were therefore carrying on in the year of account 1944-45 the business for which they were incorporated.

facts.text: Deed dated May 7, 1935 includes covenant for Associated Cement Ltd. to pay 13 annas per ton of cement sold manufactured from limestone won from transferred lands.

anchor.surface_text: That it will pay to the Vendor a sum equal to thirteen annas in respect of every ton of cement sold by it which shall have been manufactured from the limestone won by it from the lands hereby transferred and companyprised in the hereinbefore recited leases and agreements.

facts.text: Fixed consideration of Rs. 25,000 paid by Associated Cement Ltd. to appellants for trouble and expenses.

anchor.surface_text: WHEREAS it was agreed inter alia that the Purchaser should pay to the Vendor the sum of Rupees twenty five thousand for trouble and expenses in obtaining the leases and agreements dated the thirtieth day of September one thousand nine hundred and thirty four hereinbefore recited and hereinafter expressed to be hereby transferred and Whereas the Purchaser hath paid to the Vendor the said sum of rupees twenty five thousand

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J. on January 17, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Appellants retained certain rights and imposed restrictions on Associated Cement Ltd. in the deed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants undoubtedly did number part with all their rights in favour of the Associated Cement Ltd. by this deed dated May 7, 1935. The companysideration under the deed companysisted of a fixed companyponent and annual payments fluctuating with the business activity of the Associated Cement Ltd.

facts.text: Tribunal held the sum of Rs. 77,820 was a receipt of revenue nature assessable as such.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a proper companystruction of the Deed of Assignment dated 7th of May, 1935, and on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the Tribunal was right in holding that, the sum of Rs. 77,820 represented a receipt of a revenue nature in the hands of the Applicant and assessable as such

facts.text: Dewarkhand Cement Company Ltd. later known as Associated Cement Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants companyveyed to Dewarkhand Cement Company Ltd.  which later came to be known as Associated Cement Ltd. and will be referred to hereinafter by that name

facts.text: Minimum payments specified in clause 5 of deed: first year Rs.10,000, second Rs.30,000, subsequent Rs.50,000.

anchor.surface_text: During the first year to be companyputed from the first day of January one thousand nine hundred and thirty-five, rupees ten thousand. During the second year rupees thirty thousand. During every subsequent year rupees fifty thousand.

facts.text: Appellants authorised by Memorandum of Association to sell or dispose undertakings or property.

anchor.surface_text: By their Memorandum of Association, the appellants were authorised to sell or dispose of the undertakings or any part thereof as they thought fit, and to sell, lease, mortgage, dispose of, turn to account or otherwise deal with all or any part of their property and rights

facts.text: Purchaser to pay rents, royalties under original leases and indemnify vendor.

anchor.surface_text: That the Purchaser or the persons deriving title under the Purchaser will at all times from the date hereof duly pay all rents, royalties and payments becoming due under the  four  hereinbefore recited Indenture of Lease
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22/23, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1953.

At the instance of the appellants, the Tribunal referred the following question with another not material for this appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Whether on a proper construction of the Deed of Assignment dated 7th of May, 1935, and on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the Tribunal was right in holding that, the sum of Rs. 77,820 represented a receipt of a revenue nature in the hands of the Applicant and assessable as such

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ceeds derived from the sales of the biography he wrote. By the agreement, the author was authorised to extract and publish from the diaries what he th

concepts.unlisted_description: Interpretation of deed or agreement based on terms and surrounding circumstances, disregarding parties' labels

concepts.interpretation: Transaction not a complete sale due to restrictions and retained rights; constituted commercial profit-sharing, rendering receipt taxable as revenue; guided by broad principles assessing commercial character over legal form.
concepts.unlisted_description: Test to determine taxability of receipts: capital receipts (e.g., instalment sale proceeds) non-taxable; revenue receipts (e.g., annuities, profit shares, royalties, sales-based payments) taxable as income; assessed via commercial substance, contract terms, circumstances, precedents.

anchor.surface_text: But in assessing the true character of the receipt for the purpose of the Income-tax Act, inability to ascribe to the transaction a definite category is of little consequence.

concepts.interpretation: Receipts of revenue nature in commerce are assessable as income.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: warkhand Cement Company Ltd.  which later came to be known as Associated Cement Ltd. and will be referred to hereinafter

concepts.unlisted_description: Governing statute for assessment of income, including determination of revenue vs capital receipts.

issues.text: Whether on a proper construction of the Deed of Assignment dated 7th of May, 1935, and on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the Tribunal was right in holding that, the sum of Rs. 77,820 represented a receipt of a revenue nature in the hands of the Applicant and assessable as such

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal was right in holding that, the sum of Rs. 77,820 represented a receipt of a revenue nature in the hands of the Applicant and assessable as such

arguments.court_reasoning: Transaction not complete sale due to retained rights and restrictions; payments based on business activity indicate revenue nature

arguments.claim: the receipt under clause 1 of the terms of the deed dated May 7, 1935, was in the nature of capital payment

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants submitted that the receipt under clause 1 of the terms of the deed dated May 7, 1935, was in the nature of capital payment and relied upon certain decisions

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished cited precedents as based on special facts and interpretations, not general principles applicable here; transaction involves profit-sharing

arguments.claim: Appellants did not part with all their rights; numerous restrictions inconsistent with character of a sale

anchor.surface_text: The appellants undoubtedly did not part with all their rights in favour of the Associated Cement Ltd. by this deed dated May 7, 1935. The consideration under the deed consisted of a fixed component

arguments.claim: Transaction not a conveyance of all rights, not a sale, not a lease, not a joint venture

anchor.surface_text: It is not a conveyance of all the rights of the appellants nor can it be regarded as a sale even of the rights which were conveyed. Numerous restrictions were imposed by the deed upon the rights

arguments.claim: Inability to ascribe definite category of little consequence; true character determined by commercial nature, not legal form

anchor.surface_text: But in assessing the true character of the receipt for the purpose of the Income-tax Act, inability to ascribe to the transaction a definite category is of little consequence. It is not the nature

arguments.claim: Where capital repaid in instalments, not liable to tax (citing Foley, Scoble, Oswald, Ramsay)

anchor.surface_text: Where capital is repaid in instalments, it is not liable to income-tax for instance when a person sells his property and agrees to receive the price stipulated in instalments, by whatever name

arguments.claim: Annuity or periodical payments as share of profits, royalty, sales-based are taxable (citing Kameshwar Singh, Gopal Saran, Kamakshya Narain, etc.)
Spooner case not applicable; no new principle, mere interpretation based on uncertainty of oil
arguments.court_reasoning: Proceeded merely upon interpretation of the document in the light of the circumstances

arguments.claim: Earl Haig case special; diaries asset exhausted, not general principle
arguments.court_reasoning: Proceeded upon the special character of the agreement and the nature of the asset transferred

arguments.claim: Nethersole case special; complete disposal of copyright portion
arguments.court_reasoning: Wholly sold and disposed of a part of the property; amount was lump sum price

arguments.claim: Marine Steam Turbine not relevant; no trade or business there
arguments.court_reasoning: Company not carrying on trade or business; different condition of liability

arguments.claim: Appellants had not sold entirety of rights; conveyance subject to restrictions; substantially commercial profit-sharing

holdings.text: The appellants undoubtedly did not part with all their rights in favour of the Associated Cement Ltd. by this deed dated May 7, 1935. The consideration under the deed consisted of a fixed component and annual payments fluctuating with the business activity of the Associated Cement Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants undoubtedly did not part with all their rights in favour of the Associated Cement Ltd. by this deed dated May 7, 1935. The consideration under the deed consisted of a fixed component and annual payments fluctuating with the business activity of the Associated Cement Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed analysis shows retained rights and restrictions on transferee, with payments tied to business output rather than fixed capital repayment.

holdings.text: It is not a conveyance of all the rights of the appellants nor can it be regarded as a sale even of the rights which were conveyed. Numerous restrictions were imposed by the deed upon the rights of the transferee which were inconsistent in their very nature with the character of a sale, and the covenant authorising termination of the deed in the event of the limestone being exhausted removes all doubt in that behalf.

anchor.surface_text: It is not a conveyance of all the rights of the appellants nor can it be regarded as a sale even of the rights which were conveyed. Numerous restrictions were imposed by the deed upon the rights of the transferee which were inconsistent in their very nature with the character of a sale, and the covenant authorising termination of the deed in the event of the limestone being exhausted removes all doubt in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Covenants impose restrictions and allow termination, incompatible with absolute sale; examined deed terms directly.

holdings.text: Nor is it a lease it is not a transfer of a right to enjoy property for a certain time in consideration of periodical payments. It also does not evidence a transaction in the nature of a joint venture between the appellants and the Associated Cement Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it a lease it is not a transfer of a right to enjoy property for a certain time in consideration of periodical payments. It also does not evidence a transaction in the nature of a joint venture between the appellants and the Associated Cement Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fixed term enjoyment right typical of lease; no shared control or venture indicated in deed.

holdings.text: But in assessing the true character of the receipt for the purpose of the Income-tax Act, inability to ascribe to the transaction a definite category is of little consequence. It is not the nature of the receipt under the general law but in commerce that is material.

anchor.surface_text: But in assessing the true character of the receipt for the purpose of the Income-tax Act, inability to ascribe to the transaction a definite category is of little consequence. It is not the nature of the receipt under the general law but in commerce that is material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax character determined by commercial substance over legal categorization, per Income-tax Act principles.

holdings.text: The true nature and character of the transaction have to be ascertained from the covenants of the contract in the light of the surrounding circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The true nature and character of the transaction have to be ascertained from the covenants of the contract in the light of the surrounding circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard method for contract construction in tax context, disregarding labels.

holdings.text: Where capital is repaid in instalments, it is not liable to income-tax... But where property is conveyed in consideration of what in truth is annuity payable for a definite or a definable period, the annuity is not payment on capital account and is taxable... Again, if property is conveyed in consideration of periodical payments, the payment being a share of profits... or a mineral royalty... or computed on sales of manufactured articles... or a percentage of gross profits... is income and taxable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied established precedents distinguishing capital instalments from taxable revenue like annuities, profit shares, royalties, sales-based payments.

holdings.text: The judgment lays down no new principle it proceeded merely upon interpretation of the document in the light of the circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Spooner as fact-specific interpretation, not general rule for capital.

holdings.text: That decision proceeded upon the special character of the agreement and the nature of the asset transferred and did not seek to lay down any general principle.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Earl Haig due to unique asset exhaustion.

holdings.text: That was a case in which N had wholly sold and disposed of a part of the property and the amount received by her was the price paid in lump and was not in the nature of income.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Nethersole as complete disposal for lump sum.

holdings.text: In that case, a company which was on the facts found not carrying on a trade or business was held not assessable to Excess Profits Duty, because the condition of liability was the carrying on of trade or business.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Marine Steam Turbine as no business activity present.

holdings.text: The appellants had however not sold the entirety of the rights acquired by them from the Karanpura Company. The conveyance was subject to several restrictions and the appellants retained in part rights in the land conveyed. The transaction was substantially a commercial transaction for sharing the profits of the commercial activities of the Associated Cement Ltd.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizing deed construction, retained rights/restrictions, and business-linked payments characterize as profit-sharing, taxable as revenue per precedents.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 on rights not parted with under the deed dated May 7, 1935 addresses the issue of proper construction of the deed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants undoubtedly did not part with all their rights in favour of the Associated Cement Ltd. by this deed dated May 7, 1935. The consideration under the deed consisted of a fixed component and annual payments fluctuating with the business activity of the Associated Cement Ltd.

The appellants had however number sold the entirety of the rights acquired by them from the Karanpura Company. The companyveyance was subject to several restrictions and the appellants retained in part rights in the land companyveyed. The transaction was substantially a companymercial transaction for sharing the profits of the companymercial activities of the Associated Cement Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is not a conveyance of all the rights of the appellants nor can it be regarded as a sale even of the rights which were conveyed. Numerous restrictions were imposed by the deed upon the rights of the transferee which were inconsistent in their very nature with the character of a sale, and the covenant authorising termination of the deed in the event of the limestone being exhausted removes all doubt in that behalf.

The appellants had however number sold the entirety of the rights acquired by them from the Karanpura Company.
